text: Christa Sedlatachek stressed the importance of demographic change and the need to increase our workability.
Dr Sedlatschek discusses the Online Interactive Risk .assessment tool (OiRA) and the Agency's campaign, now the world's biggest.
Dr Sedlatschek outlines the challenges to OSH before tackling some of the solutions and how EU-OSHA can contribute to providing them.
Dr Sedlatschek defends the importance of workplace health and safety in Europe.
Christa Sedlatschek, Director EU-OSHA, takes the floor in the Greek presidency OSH conference in Athens #gr2014eu  #SafetyandHealth
The Commission encourages stakeholders to develop tools and instruments.  EU-OSHA and Eurofound are very important.
The Commission promotes cooperation between Labour Inspectorates in Europe, says Mr Silva.
SMEs are recognized in the new strategic OSH framework.  They have special needs and OiRA fills some of them, says Mr Silva.
There is no use in having ambitious legislation if compliance is poor, says Mr Silva.  Enforcement is key.
The strategic framework makes it clear on where the main hazards lie in the future, added Mr Silva.
But European legislation must be of very high quality, says Mr Silva.  That is key.
Minimum standards on OSH are necessary and Europe remains committed, commented Mr Silva.
The conference is timely because the Commission has just published a new strategic framework for OSH, says Mr Silva.
Mr Silva says that Europe's economies are indeed showing signs of recovery.  But it is uneven and we must promote OSH.
Mr Armindo Silva from the European Commission takes the floor and congratulates the Greek Presidency #SafetyandHealth
When we talk about growth and development, OSH is a crucial index to help us measure world economies, says Greek minister.
Minister Vroutsis presents European and ILO statistics on the very high costs of accidents and illnesses.
Minister Vroutsis says that there are convincing arguments for investing a little in OSH because the return is very beneficial.
Minister Vroutsis says that gradually we are exiting the crisis #healthandsafety
Minister Vroutsis says that OSH is central to the EU Presidency and to Europe's goals, despite being in a very difficult time.
Antonius Christodoulou welcomes everyone and introduces the Minister of Labour, Social Security and Welfare, Ioannis Vroutsis.
The EU Presidency conference on the future of occupational health and safety has just opened in Athens #SafetyandHealth

Lovely morning in Brussels ahead of the European launch of our new campaign. #Eumanagestress

I believe EU-OSHA will continue its good collaboration with EC to improve safety and health at work, Commissioner Andor said.
Spanish Deputy Secretary for Employment&Social Security Llorente & EU-OSHA Director Dr Sedlatschek signed a Seat Agreement between Spain &EU

RT @MartinSchulz: Thanks @EU_OSHA By informing, monitoring & researching health & safety at work, agency helps raising EU standards http://…
RT @aitormoriyon: @MartinSchulz ya está en Bilbao. Ahora reunido con el staff de @EU_OSHA. Agradece su trabajo y compromiso @PE_Espana http…
@MartinSchulz learns first-hand about the main projects and activities at @EU_OSHA http://t.co/rWBRaExaau

RT @MartinSchulz: About to pay visit to @EU_OSHA in Bilbao. EU must help creating new jobs, but must also ensure existing ones are safer&he…
New research guides design of 2014 ESENER survey — Safety and Health at Work - EU-OSHA http://t.co/O4JBqWbjdO
Healthy Workplaces Campaign 2014-2015: The countdown begins — Safety and Health at Work - EU-OSHA http://t.co/xZAwcjVvCU
Wind energy: healthy for the environment, but how healthy for workers? — Safety and Health at Work - EU-OSHA http://t.co/p0hT81AYHO
Traineeship opportunity with EU-OSHA (6 months agreement) — Safety and Health at Work - EU-OSHA http://t.co/piPayp5Cpn
We are looking for trainees for our Brussels Liaison Office.  Check out our website if you are interested or know anyone interested.
RT @PPEorg: 19% of EU workers report being exposed to toxic vapours for 25% of their work time. http://t.co/QP4kgdPKR2 @EU_OSHA #EU_OSHA #O…
RT @PPEorg: Leading by example helps establish a positive H&S culture and underpins the engagement of staff: http://t.co/mzRUuIqXu6 @EU_OSH…
That's it.  Very interesting conference.
Professor James Bridges closed the conference.  I will tweet when I find the conference presentations on the website. @EU_Social
We all need to keep in mind that it is the workers' health that we are trying to protect from old and new workplace risks, says Mr Richelle
Policy-making in OSH area is complex but subject to impact assessments, consultations, cost-benefit analyses and so on. Complicated!
We are working on an EU OSH policy framework and we will have one in the future.  Still working on it, says Mr Richelle.
Harmonization is a difficult subject but voluntary open methods of comparability would be worth exploring, says the Director General.
We can profit from collaboration with the international partners here, such as the ILO, says Mr Richelle.
The air we are breathing can be a genuine occupational health issue, says Mr Richelle,Director General of DG Employment, European Commission
The Commission is setting up a website on this topic for everyone to make their contribution in the future, announces Mr Richelle.
We have to move on and reflect on new developments in this field, says Mr Richelle.
Sometimes, occupational health and safety is regarded as a cost, instead of part of our proud record in Europe, says Mr Richelle.
Mr Richelle wraps up the meeting and warmly thanks everyone for attending the debate.  It is not an easy time to discuss this. @EU_Social
To close this conference, we will have Koos Richelle, Director General of DG EMPL of the European Commission.  @EU_Social
In DG Health, they are working on many approaches to chronic diseases, says Mr Huebel.
Your vision to have disease-free workers may come true, but will you have disease-free citizens?  Question by Mr Huebel to the audience.
The periods where people are in ill health are more than the periods where they are in good health and is a challenge for ageing population
Occupational exposure contributes to the overall burden of disease, says Mr Huebel.

annotations.normalized_text: DG Sanco of the European Commission

text: Mr MIchael Huebel from DG Sanco of the European Commission says how pleased he is that the public health element is included here.
Modernet aims to detect and validate new OH risks an an early stage.  One group deals with Quality of Data which reviews systems.
Next up is Dr Melanie Carder from Manchester University on Data Collection Mechanisms.
Presentations are worth looking out for on the Commission website as the conference has very interesting speakers. @EU_Social
Dr Vincent Bonneterre from Grenoble University, France, is up next presenting the OD sentinel clinical watch system project from France.
Opportunities for learning across EU on innovation in different types of workplace, says Dr McDaid.
There are business benefits if you have better health at work.  A strong role for governments and social insurers, says the LSE expert.
Without early intervention poor mental health may increase poor physical health, says Dr McDaid.
Provide financial incentives and other public sector support for workplace health promotion, he advocates.
We must improve links between OSH services and mainstream health systems, says Dr McDaid of the LSE
He illustrates the net return on investment for employers.  Companies bear the cost, but they get the return! Dr McDaid from LSE.
More people claim disability for mental health in the UK, huge cost to the economy.
There are social costs of alcohol use, says Dr McDaid.
You can reduce the impacts of presenteeism and absenteeism, says Dr McDaid, by focusing on mental health issues in your workplaces.
Poorly managed four times less likely to retain staff talent within a 12 month period, says Dr McDaid.
Have a look at Survey on Wellness and Business Effectiveness, Dornan & Jane-Llopis, 2010.
Investing in mental health promotes better workplace performance, encourages creativity and dialogue,
But there are also major economic impacts, says Dr McDaid of the LSE
Investing in mental health contributes to population health goals and promotes social inclusion, says Dr McDaid.
Dr David McDaid, London School of Economics says there are potential benefits to employers, employees and govts of better mental health
The Commission reminds us that all presentations from the workshops will be posted on the Commission website. @EU_Social
RT @NIOSHFACE: @NIOSHFACE Did you know injuries from use of nail guns hospitalize more construction workers than any other tool? http://t.c…
Rosa McNamee from Manchester University says that there other data systems apart from compensation systems that are very effective.
Prof John from Osnabrueck University says that the definition of an OD is very crucial. Very little money spent on prevention!
Rolf Gehring from construction unions says that the main problem is existing asbestos in existing buildings.  Recycling is the issue!
If REACH and the ECHA says there is a risk, then it would be reviewed, says DG Sanco representative.
Representative from DG Sanco says that there is no spread of asbestos fibres in these plants.
Laurent Vogel says there is no asbestos ban.  Germany and Poland are still importing asbestos for two plants! @EU_Social
RT @obspascal: Youth Unemployment And The Faux European Recovery  - good piiece http://t.co/vPXiax29ep
The European labour force survey also has questions on mental health, informs Mr De Norre from Eurostat.
Kris de Meester who should report from first workshop is not available yet so the discussion will begin and that report will be taken later.
Dr Mukala said that we need systems and limit values based on science and we need to be aware of the uncertainty that lies behind them.
You might have noticed, photography is not my forte.
Our colleague Elke Schneider and beside her the Chair, Dr Jesus Alvarez-Hidalgo from the European Commission. http://t.co/OPUouyk3le
The light isn't great in here but that is our own Dr Elke Schneider from EU-OSHA on the podium on the left. http://t.co/Ynx0mHQ78Z
That particular workshop which I attended was excellent, including an overview of the French programme on mesothelioma and asbestos.
Dr Kristiina Mukala from Finland reports from the exposure to chemicals in the workplace and cancer workshop from the previous day.
Dr Schneider is convinced that there are solutions out there and by information-sharing SMEs can do it!
Dr Schneider comments that an emphasis on personal protective equipment and individual measures can be an obstacle to prevention...
Dr Schneider says the changing world of work and fragmentation of lives must be taken into account.
Elke Schneider says that there is an observed increase in notified diseases. Some old diseases need new approaches to effective prevention.
Dr Schneider concludes that current strategies are not effective or adequately implemented for hearing loss and noise at work problems.
Are current policy and practice frameworks in Europe able to tackle psychosocial risks?  Serious increase in mental health issues.
Elke Schneider thanks the Commission for the conference.  There was a clear link between the workshop on 'old' risks and the plenary topics.
The first session looks at the workshop activities. Elke Schneider from EU-OSHA reports on 'old' workplace risks and related diseases.
Day Two of the European Commission's conference on Occupational Diseases in the EU: "Together for disease-free workers" here in Brussels.
@AragonValley OSH specialists, OSH savvy, OSH aware kids and teenagers...
The Chair concludes and says that it is important to remember that asbestos remains such a worrying and topical issue.
@StephaanVanDamm list of Occupational Diseases.  Sorry if wasn't clear.
Lively discussion now, following all the presentations and workshops today. Nearly out of battery (again).Another twitterfest tomorrow maybe
The Director emphasizes interactive nature of OIRA and the OSHWiki.  Exciting times ahead! She didn't say that. I did...
Dr Sedlatschek ran through the main projects of a busy work programme.  Our website is interactive and responsive.
Christa Sedlatschek addresses the European Commission conference on Occupational Diseases in the EU. @EU_Social http://t.co/cqBglCiGCd
We will publish a new report on women at work - it is much anticipated.  Women's health impact is under-estimated, said the Director.
The Agency is having a new look at old diseases such as noise-related health effects.
EU-OSHA now has its own multiannual strategic programme in place adopted by the tripartite Governing Board.  It will run until 2020.
Dr Sedlatschek outlines the agency's work and the five priority areas. She also mentioned the Agency's Older Worker project.
Dr Sedlatschek addresses the importance of effective information and dissemination tools.
The director of EU-OSHA, Dr Christa Sedlatschek, takes the floor for the final presentation of a packed day. Keeping the best till last?
ILO encourages each country to have a list system.  It relieves the worker from the burden of proof. But lists  can be restrictive!
The last ILO estimates were released in 2011. There are more than 6,300 work related deaths every day, says Dr Niu.
The ILO system and activities is now presented by Dr Shengli Niu.  He refers to the global statistics on OD.
No one surveillance system is comprehensive, concludes Dr Calvert.
Some concerns in the USA about flavour-related lung disease,  silica exposure during fracking, poisoning from methyl bromide...
Dr Calvert looks at data sources in the USA. I'm guessing the Commission might put these presentations on their website. @EU_Social
Across the Atlantic now and we have Dr Geoffrey Calvert from Ohio University addressing features of the USA sentinel and OD surveillance.
Melbourne is Australia's most liveable city, concludes Professor Sim.
Australia has a big interest in improving OSH in Asia.  They are helping improve diagnosis in China for occupational diseases.
The Australians are noting an emerging issue with workplace bullying.  It is a major problem, says Professor Sim.
Both the German and Australian speakers focused a lot of attention on the scourge of asbestos.
Would somebody tell Apple their battery life policy needs an overhaul please?
The first was Dr Andreas Kranig from Germany and the second Prof Malcolm Sim from Monash University all the way from Australia.
We have had two excellent speakers just now at the European Commission's conference on occupational disease. @EU_Social
The UK has enough legislation, says Ms Clayton.  Compliance is the key.
Kate Sweeney from the UK also presents on current issues there.
Stress and MSDs dominate in the UK, whatever source is used according to Ms Clayton.
Next up is Karen Clayton from the UK Health and Safety Executive. Ms Clayton provides an overview of the data sources they use.
Back in plenary in the European Commission's conference on Occupational Diseases in the EU. @EU_Social
@esteruco not possible I'm afraid.  Sorry.
What is important to notice is that many important carcinogens are not covered by REACH legislation, says Dr Santonen.
Really interesting Commission conference here in Brussels.Final speaker in cancer workshop is Dr Tiina Santonen from the Finnish Institute.
Since the last century, there has been a drastic evolution in the perception of 'risk' from carcinogenic exposures, says Dr Huici-Montagud.
Dr Alicia Huici-Montagud explained the use of non-thresholds in the past.
Dr Alicia Huici-Montagud, from Spain, presents on Thresholded vs Non-Thresholded carcinogens and occupational diseases.
The study concluded that OSHA PEL insufficiently protects against lung cancer and silicosis.  OSHA has proposed a revised PEL.
Dr Calvert used death certificate data in his research.
The OSHA standard cited Calvert et al study as corroborative evidence.
Dr Calvert provides background to OSHA standard on silica.
Dr Geoffrey Calvert, Ohio University USA is speaking on "Silica and cancer - use of death certificate and other data to lower the PEL."
First up on the topic is Dr Anabelle Gilg Soit Ilg presenting "Asbestos - The French system of mesothelioma surveillance" from INVS, France
So, the workshops are beginning.  Workshop 4 is on Exposure to chemicals in the workplace and cancer.
The next session of the OD Conference here in Brussels is not in plenary, but in workshops.  Back later.
We have a lot of knowledge, says Mr Vogel, but our biggest issue is political inaction.
Mr Vogel said he is not naive to think that the Scientific Committee would solve everything.
Mr Vogel says that work-related cancers cannot be compared with electromagnetic fields.
Mr Vogel said that the electromagnetic field example is not a good one to show.  We can define limit values.  But we only have three.
In the case of OD, there is no EU harmonized system, says Mr Vogel from the trade unions.  A scientific committee cannot do this work!
We have a clear regulatory framework for the other scientific committees and they are important, says Mr Vogel.
Most Member States show that women are compensated in less than one third of cases.  The gap in cancers is huge, says Mr Vogel.
Mr Vogel says there is indirect discrimination against women.  If you look at the practice from the list to compensation there is a gap.
Ms Smith from the employers doesn't think there can be harmonization of social security systems.
Ms Smith thinks that the science is important but the choice of what is an OD remains with the Member State and should be so.
We are proud of our legislative record but we do make mistakes and have some issues to resolve.  Electromagnetic fields for example.
The Commission spends a lot of time evaluating the ex ante impact of measures.  Very important in area of carcinogens.
Mr Silva said that there wont be legislative initiatives during the current Commission.  But evaluation work is going on! It's important.
Mr Silva from the Commission says that OSH is still a priority for the Commission and it oversees implementation of legislation.
A number of audience members support the establishment of a Scientific Committee on Occupational Disease.
@AragonValley  Indeed.
Mr Costa-David thinks there is room for science and for a Scientific Committee.
Mr Seitz says that this is a struggle for workers everywhere.
Mr Seitz asks, who fought against asbestos in France?  The workers did!  Not the employers.They should assume responsibility.
Gilles Seitz from the French trade unions says that the issue of OD is not a medical one, it is a political one.
Dutch inspectorate wants more details on women's discrimination.
Mr Taylor on behalf of the governments said there could be more transparency in decision-making.
Social security is the area of national competence, says Mr Taylor. He supports idea of non-binding recommendation.
Government priority is prevention and compensation to those who have suffered.The existing framework is fine. New legislation not required.
Mr Taylor said that governments across the EU take ODs very seriously.  Action is very important and there is a legal framework.
To give the government view, Mr Stephen Taylor, from the UK Health and Safety Executive takes the floor.
And Ms Smith concluded by emphasizing the non-binding nature of the instrument.
No need for a new structure, says Ms Smith.  We have the Advisory Committee and that is tripartite.
Ms Smith does not support the establishment of the Scientific Committee on OD because it should have social partner representation.
Business Europe has concerns that the Commission wants Member States to report back to the Commission, says Ms Smith.
There is a need to improve mobility across the EU, but doesn't see this as a barrier to mobility, says Ms Smith.
The Recommendation should remain as one and not be transformed into something more binding, said Ms Smith.
There are different starting points in different Member States, says Ms Smith.  There isn't any move to convergence.
The Recommendation has made a difference, says Ms Smith of Business Europe.  @EU_Social
There is a raft of EU legislation to protect workers, says Ms Smith.
Occupation diseases are where there is a causal link between exposure and effect.
Important to distinguish between occupational diseases and work-related ill-health, says Ms Smith. Root cause is sometimes difficult to find
Rebekah Smith of the employers' organization Business Europe welcomes the Commission report.
Mr Vogel says they have blocked the cancer and MSD initiative, no EU strategy and no hairdresser initiative despite social partner consensus
Mr Vogel said that we can talk a lot but where is the action?  We have stopped acting on so many levels.
EUROSTAT defines OD as a negative priority.  What is that? Mr Vogel asks. Do serious work on OD.  It is difficult for sure.
We need post employment health surveys because there can be a long period between exposure time and disease onset. Huge challenge.
It is always fine to have good practice but that is not the role of a recommendation.  That is for Bilbao EU-OSHA, says Mr Vogel.
We should look at OD in the social security systems and take action against discrimination of women.
He doesn't support the establishment of a Scientific Committee if it doesn't involve the workers and the employers.
Mr Vogel says that occupational disease is a legal  concept for the purpose of compensation.Our approach should be less technocratic.
Mr Vogel says that the Commission has not acted on cancers or MSDs.
Mr Vogel said that prevention is a key issue but we are in a very negative political context.  No strategy for OSH.
The gender issue should be better addressed in the Commission report, says Mr Vogel.  There is structural discrimination against women.
There is massive discrimination against women when speaking about occupational disease in Europe, says Mr Vogel.
Laurent Vogel, trade unions, says there should be a greater tripartite input to the conference, not just on the Round Table.
Professor John says that there are some very good examples of social agreements, such as in the hairdressing sector.
There should be no occupational health without occupational mental health, concludes Prof Siegrist.
We need robust scientific evidence on mental health, increased awareness, national labour and social policies and better return to work
@svaxelaire thank you, Stephan.
We need to apply existing regulations, develop voluntary agreements and maintain and strengthen national labour and social policies.
There is a clear link between skill levels and exposure to stress, says Professor Siegrist.
Psychosocial stress at work and depressive symptoms are not only European phenomena.  You also find them in Japan and USA.
He presents evidence from prospective cohort studies which he describes as the gold standard.
How can we identify the toxic components in modern work environments? Prof Siegrist runs through the models.
There is a huge risk of mental health problems of those who are unemployed, so losing their jobs can make people even worse.
Mental health causes a double burden of absenteeism, presenteeism and early disability-related retirement. And elevates risk of depression.
Now we turn to Professor Johannes Siegrist from the University of Dusseldorf in Germany on work-related mental health problems.
A modern MSD directive would be an important message for everyone who suffers from it and would give visibility to MSDs, says Mr Piette.
@svaxelaire I'm quoting the name printed on the programme!
Almost 11 billion euro is the cost of MSDs to the Belgian companies, says Mr Piette.
8 out of 10 workers will suffer from MSDs, said Mr Piette. @EU_Social
Mr Allan Piette is of course from Belgium, not France as stated just now.
Next up addressing work related musculoskeletal disorders (MSDs) is Mr Allan Piette from France.
The correct name of that last speaker on asbestos: Dr Gert van der Laan of the Netherlands Center for Occupational Diseases.
Asbestos is an old problem but it will be with us for years, concludes Dr van der Laan.
We should reduce delays and strengthen labour inspectorates, says Dr van der Leen.
The burden of asbestos related diseases is high.  The numbers and costs are high.  No one forecasted the epidemic for construction workers.
He quotes data by Jukka Takala.
The economic costs of occupational diseases are difficult to calculate, says Dr van der Leen.
The epidemic is shifting towards Russia, Kazakhstan and Brazil.
The European mesothelioma epidemic will peak around 2015 in Western Europe and later in Eastern Europe.
The overall burden of asbestos related mortality in Europe is still dramatic, says Dr van der Leen.
There are many waves of exposure to asbestos. There is a lot we do not know, says Dr van der Laan. @EU_Social
Some patients have very short exposure to asbestos, but there is a lack of data on exposure. @EU_Social
Mr van der Laan presents figures on mesothelioma for the Netherlands.  There is a shift in the profile of sufferers.
Mr van der Laan says he is ashamed that we didn't stop this asbestos problem earlier.
Gert van der Laan presents the burden of asbestos-related diseases in the EU.
Now conference examines three topical issues: asbestos, MSDs and work-related mental health problems. @EU_Social

There should be better training of medical students and physicians in occupational health, says Costa-David.
